recordings.loc: Teller road, Nome, Alaska
Teller road, Nome, Alaska
Teller road, Nome, Alaska
Teller road, Nome, Alaska
Oxford, Lafayette County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Natural sound. Flushed from grass onto partridgepea and then into small sapling ~10m away. Issued two high buzzy calls before flying away.

#Habitat#
State waterfowl refuge along the margins of USACE flood control reservoir. Strip along the lake margins ~1km wide of moist soil grassland with mix of forbs, native warm season grasses (Andropogon, Schyzachyrium, Eragrostis, Aristida, etc.), and some sparse woody vegetation (Cephalanthus, Quercus saplings, etc.) bounded by oak hickory forest and, in places, pine plantation.  Three or four shallow waterfowl impoundments partially flooded in the winter.

#Editing#
Edited in Adobe Audition. Butterworth high-pass filter, order 3, cutoff frequency 1kHz

#Equipment#
Fostex FR-2 digital recorder with Sennheiser microphone and Telinga pro 22" parabolic reflector.

recordings.loc: Halifax (near  Black Point), Halifax Regional Municipality, Nova Scotia
recordings.rmk:
Singing from dense low shrubs at edge of forest and clear-cut habitats.

Sang similar song 4 times from same general location  over an 8-12 minute period. Sang at irregular intervals with several minutes passing between each song. After singing 4 times the bird stopped or left the area and was not seen.

See https://www.xeno-canto.org/564003 for another song from the same bird recorded just before this one.

recordings.loc: Hallo Bay, Alaska
recordings.file-name: XC535154-KATMHALO_20180704_162113 low quality Lincoln's Sparrow song.MP3
recordings.rmk: Site was placed near the tip of a long spit at the southern end of Hallo Bay. About 50 meters north of the site is a lagoon formed by Hallo Creek. A small eddy in the creek about 1.7 km from the site serves as a float pond. At high tide the site was about 80 - 90 meters from the ocean. Viereck Class III.A.1.a. Dry Graminoid Herbaceous Elymus.

recordings.rmk: migrant or wintering bird, singing softly or very softly from only 4m away, hard for me to hear; about 1 m up in mesquite thicket, preening much of the time; this species rarely sings as a migrant in this area; quite possibly the same bird as recorded twice earlier today and yesterday, this a much longer recording; just singing parts of a song in the middle, and some rather odd songs toward the end (subsong/learning/practicing?)

recordings.loc: 4 (near  Mansfield), Red River Parish, Louisiana
recordings.rmk: 2 birds. Across levee from marker.  When first hearing, I was quite sure the distant bird calling (1st in cut) approx 50' to southeast was Fox. However, it was observed calling, bill movements matching every smack. Just goes to show how different they can sound depending on position. Distant bird's position was also slightly closer to levee, possibly adding to the hollow Fox Sparrow-like quality of the call.

recordings.loc: Red River National Wildlife Refuge, Bayou Pierre unit, Yates tract
recordings.rmk:
Lincoln's Sparrow (2) were at the exact location, observed slightly after making the recording. Although I did not see the bird calling while making the recording, I am 99.9% sure of the identity, based on sound, vs Swamp Sparrow. My decision is based on the rough quality of the sound, although not ascending slightly as usual. No SWSP were recorded that day. Possible chip note also audible here.
Edit- After further looking, we did have Swamp Sparrow that day. However, I still stand behind the chosen identification regarding this sound file.

Big Pines Meadow, San Gabriel Mountains, Los Angeles County, California
recordings.rmk:
Lincoln's sparrow singing at one of small number of known breeding sites in Los Angeles County.  This is at a meadow next to the parking lot for the Mountain High Ski Area.   

Modifications to the file: I cropped the beginning and end.

Open meadow with grasses, flowers, and short willows, surrounded by forest with white fir, Jeffrey pine, sugar pine, and black oak.

The bird was singing from low a clump of willows less than 10 meters from me.  The bird was about 1 meter above the ground.

recordings.loc: YMCA of the Rockies
Algonquin Highlands, Haliburton County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: Finally able to record this bird. It has been in this little Tamarack labrador tea bog all year but very rarely show itself. This is the southern edge of breeding range and it is quite a rare summer bird in this area.

recordings.loc: South Fork Cottonwood Creek, Inyo County, California
recordings.rmk:
Brief recording uploaded primarily for documentation.  This appeared in the background of a much louder red crossbill recording.  The bird was singing off to my right and was not along the line-of-sight of the shotgun microphone.

Although we didn't see this individual, we heard and saw a different Lincoln's sparrow several hundred meters farther west about five minutes earlier. 

Equipment: Olympus LS-10S with a Sennheiser MKE-400 microphone.

Modifications to the file: cropped and amplified by 10 dB.
